raw_text: Stevenson and Wilks (2001) presented a classifier combination framework where 3 disambiguation methods (simulated annealing, subject codes and selectional restrictions) were combined using the TiMBL memory-based approach (Daelemans et al, 1999) .Pedersen (2000) presents experiments with an ensemble of Na ?ve Bayes classifiers, which outperform all previous published results on two ambiguous words (line and interest)

raw_text: Stevenson and Wilks (2001) propose a somewhat related technique to handle WSD, based on integrating LDOCE classes with simulated annealing. raw_text: However, both (Peder sen, 2001a) and (Lee and Ng, 2002) suggest that different learning algorithms result in little change in overall disambiguation results, and that the real determiner of accuracy is the set of features that are employed. Previous work has shown that using different combinations of features is advantageous for word sense disambiguation (e.g., (McRoy, 1992), (Ng and Lee, 1996), (Stevenson and Wilks, 2001), (Yarowsky and Florian, 2002))
